LeadPara.Para: VARIETY PUZZLE -- Cryptic crosswords are a unique form of punishment. If you like tricky clues in regular grids, though, you owe yourself to try them. At first, if it seems as if the rules are inscrutable, don't bail out; this is a very popular type of puzzle in other spheres, so there's great, detailed solving information available online (Deb Amlen recommends this guide -- try using it as a road map today).

TailParas.Para: I've worked on cryptic puzzles for years, and have grown very fond of them. The experts say that the key to understanding each clue is recognizing its two parts; one is a standard definition or synonym, and the other is some form of paronomasia that adds a layer of interest and possibly leads you to an unusual solution. You definitely develop a knack for seeing the twist on each clue, but it also especially helps, in these puzzles, to recognize the fun in the journey and not beat yourself up for being unable to finish without an assist (especially from your fellow solvers in the comments).

The easiest clues for me are the anagrams; they're akin to multiple choice, as far as I'm concerned, as the answer is there, just scrambled. There will usually be a tip that the scramble needs to happen in the clue: look for a word like ''doctor'' (17D), ''rocks'' (23A), or ''deciphered'' (27A). Any word meaning disrupt, rearrange, or change can be a clue to what to do.

For example, the 27A: ''Acrostic deciphered: a country'' (5,4). First of all, as in most cryptics, you're given a hint in letter count that indicates more than one word, in this case a two-word phrase of five and then four letters. I look at the number of letters in each word; in this case, acrostic has eight letters, but if you add that ''a'' in ''a country,'' you get nine, so that's a good tip. If you rearrange the letters in ''acrostic,'' and add an a, with an eye to the information above, you arrive at COSTA RICA. Not bad, right? You can do this with those other two clues above -- ''doctor claimed,'' for 17A, to get MEDICAL, and ''paper said rocks'' for the other, DISAPPEAR. The order of the words in a clue can sometimes be altered to further challenge the solver.

The anagram can also be one ingredient in a more complex recipe, like at 9A and 19A, among others. Let's look at 19A: ''Mull liquor in blended tea'' (8). The anagram indicator is ''blended,'' so I guessed that ''liquor in,'' comprising eight letters, might be anagrammed for the answer, perhaps a synonym to ''mull.'' I came up empty, though, but the misdirection got me thinking of words like ''mull'': ponder, consider, cogitate. ... How about RUMINATE? If you work backward a bit, ''rum'' is a synonym for liquor, ''in'' an anagram of tea: ''ate.''

Of course, there are plenty of clues with no anagrams at all. Some are punny synonyms, usually in sequence or folded in on one another. Let's look at 3D, ''Artist to glue one thing after another'' (9). One way to see ''one thing after another'' would be a repeated word, like ''Duran Duran'' or ''Humbert Humbert.'' I was looking for an artist though, and we also needed to keep ''to glue'' in the mix; one important thing to remember is that there aren't any wasted words in these clues. It turns out that this entry is an example of a definition that comprises one definition plus another definition; the first is PASTE, for ''to glue,'' and the second is LIST, ''one thing after another.'' Your artist is a PASTELIST. Other examples of this are at 4A, 14A, 28A, 2D and 21D.

There are other tricks. Keep an eye on instructions like ''review'' or ''upset'' (which can mean you need to reverse letters); ''suppressing,'' ''containing,'' ''about'' (indications that one word will be enclosed in another to get your ultimate solution); and ''ultimately'' or ''starting,'' among others, to indicate that you'll be using either the first or last letter of a word, or removing the first or last letter to get a word.

Finally, be flexible. After I gave you that spiel about ''doctor'' meaning ''rearrange,'' you get to 8D: ''Doctor Rush operating'' (7). Anagramming won't work here, none of the letters add up, so, ''What on earth?'' Turns out this is a couple of synonyms -- SURGE for ''Rush'' and ON for ''operating'' -- that'll get you a synonym for the word you were thinking of as a modifier, not a subject. Fiendish.

The grids that we publish, like today's, are formatted and presented like daily puzzles from The Financial Times and The Times of London (see below). There are plenty of wilder variations available online; one I particularly like, but don't often finish on my own, is the monthly puzzle at the back of Harper's Magazine.
